remixed_from.title: Parametric Involute  Bevel and Spur Gears

description.text:
IMPORTANT NOTE: This will not work on a Prusa i3 or really anything that is complete and available. I think the design is pretty cool, but you'd need to build a machine around it. This is combined carriage and extruder for 70mm spaced vertical x-axis. It uses 4 lm8uu bearings and can be removed from the machine without tools or disassembly of the x-axis. With the idler open the hobbed bolt and gear can be removed and cleaned without tools. I've done an extruder test and it rides nicely on the rails, but i wont be able to print anything with it until i build the rest of the machine.
X-ends available here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:18539

Print. I've printed this in ABS with some warping, PLA might be better.
I recomend infill of 50% or higher. The extruder itself is very similar to other wade designs. Except the drive bolt, all hardware is M3.

title: Simple 1/4 Tripod Mount iPhone 6 Plus - single part no screws

description.text:
Inspired by - see remix - I have created a new version from scratch that actually fits a iPhone 6 Plus with the original Apple Leather Case.

I created it for studio work with my iPhone. It does 240 FPS for slow motion effects. This is a nice extension to my Nikon which is limited to 60 FPS. It works great on my tripod. You can even align the mount point with the side optical axis.

Disclaimer: The mount is not meat for action style outdoor activities since the grip might not be strong enough for holding the iPhone securely.

Printer Brand:

Up!

Printer:

Up Mini

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3 mm layer

Infill:

loose - 30%

Notes:

Print it oriented as is on the side with no support. The 1/4 inch standard thread should print fine. On my printer it is a strong fit for the tripod screw and it holds well.

The material I used is PLA with Aluminium infusion, so it makes a nice finish. However PLA is rather scratchy to the leather, so use sanding or a file on the mount to make it soft.

title: Modular tool bracket for IKEA LACK table

description.text:
This is a tool holding bracket that clips onto an IKEA LACK table, or it can be screwed in somewhere if need be. I haven't had any trouble with it coming un-clipped, but the counter-sunk screw hole is there just in case. The bracket part of this thing has 12 square holes that can be used to arrange the accompanying modules in many different ways.

Each of these modules has two sets of flexing, square-fitting feet and one square hole on top so that modules can be stacked two deep for extended tool-holding ability. I am including the SketchUp file so anyone who wishes to add more tool-specific modules can do so easily.

Finally, the square holes on the bracket portion are close enough to the edge that modules can be used to connect adjacent brackets. I have only printed one, so no pictures of this feature yet.

I hope to add more tool-specific modules in the future when I figure out what they could be.

UPDATE:
I cleaned up the sketchup file and added labels to clarify what is what and why it is there

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa i3

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

30

Notes:

Mine print with with rafts and supports, but it may be fine without rafts.

I tried to print the module portion with feet pointing up and no supports but it didn't work well at all. I now print them on their sides (as in the STL file) with supports for the feet and it prints fine.

Fine-tuning

I usually use a flat rasp on the sides where the feet had supports to completely remove the support material. If this part gets too much filing, the modules don't fit as securely so be careful there.

This is an update of this thing - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1715175

It's based on this library - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:3575/#files

Now both gears has the same number of teeth (10 teeth), which result in a lot more powerful diff (larger teeth, harder to break), and a smaller diff at the same time (less teeth, smaller gear size). However, the ratio is now 1:1.

The STL files you have here are designed so that the large gear has 16 mm in diameter. Should you want a larger or a smaller diff, just alter the "SCALE_FACTOR" variable in the OpenScad source code and regenerate.

See a test here - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Fl0kDC48Tu8

This design uses 4 bearings (D8 x d5 x 2.5 mm). You can however customize the bearing size (check "BEARING_OUTER_DIAMETER" and "BEARING_WIDTH" variables).

This design uses 4 M2 pins to fix the gears on the axle (the axle is drilled before). You can change that (see "GEAR_FIX_SCREW_DIAMETER").

This design uses 5 mm precision rods. You can change that (see "GEAR_BORE_DIAMETER" variable).

You can generate an open axle (where you can see the gears inside) by calling "axle_top(open_top=1);" and you can generate closed axle (so that no dust gets inside) by calling "axle_top(open_top=0);".

title: Filament Spool Weight / Screw Cap Container

description.text:
UPDATE 15DEC2017: I have added a newer design that is slightly smaller to fit through a larger variety of spool holes. I have also made it better balanced (although it wasn't a problem before) and a little faster print since it's shorter (but can fit nearly the same amount of weight as before).

I made this to weigh down filament spools that were getting near empty. Due to the lighter weight and the greater instances of filament tangles as the filament runs out, my spools have been pulled off the filament rollers by the filament stepper motor. I found adding a weight on the inside of the spool held it down without adding much of any additional friction to the system.

The screw cap intentionally fits tightly to aid in watertightness. You can break it in by screwing and unscrewing it a few times.

To use, fill the container with heavy weight (I used 90 x 1.5", 5/16 hole washers on a 5" long, 1/4" bolt, which added 2lbs of weight). It does hold water without leaking but this depends on what settings you choose to print it with.

The filament spool weight goes well with my filament spool roller. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2250077

description.text:
Upgrade to the existing y axis plywood bearing block. The little plywood plate that holds the bearing is a couple mm too long along its axis enabling the bearings to move during rapid direction changes despite how tight the zip ties are. This is accurate to the bearing and press fits in very tightly. Uses existing holes to mount to the base of the bed carriage. Holes for zip ties are also there but doesn't necessarily need them as the curved walls and tight long ways fit hold the bearings very secure.

Not sure if it will fit other i3 builds but is made for the current CTC prusa setup.

Hope it helps and enjoy!

PS: This was all part of preventing slippage on the y axis that was causing shifting layers. Turns out the biggest culprit was the timing belt pulley not being fully secured to the motor shaft. Make sure you tighten those grub screws very tight!

title: Ninebot One rear mount for tail light, reflector and licenseplate

description.text:
This is a pretty generic mount adapter, that offers a rectangular contour where an attachment with a matching contour can be connected using a simple bolt.

It adapts to the curved body shape of a Ninebot One E+ electric unicycle and consists of multiple parts. The central part with the connecting contour (gummi-einsatz.stl) should be made out of flexible ("rubber") filament, While the other parts (with the screw holes should be made from ABS or PLA.

Designed to print on a tinyboy fabricator, hence the long part (rumpfteil.stl) was split with a zig-zag line into two (rumpfteil_oben.stl and rumpfteil_unten.stl) that fit into the 8x8cm print area of a tinyboy. These two pieces should be glued together, (or on any other printer, just print rumpfteil.stl instead)

There is an extra tail part (endstueck_haken_gummi.stl) that offers an extra mounting hole (7x7mm square) This piece is useful to add a red reflector (german STVO asks for a type Z reflector). This extra part should be printed with rubber filament, so that it does not break, when it hits the ground.

There is an extra cylindrical nob at the top, to allow for mounting a taillight. I recommend the extra bright Albrilo Lipo LED light available from e.g. https://www.amazon.de/gp/product/B01FXD4HG6

For the front, there is a headlight mount here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1687113

Done with FreeCAD 0.17

The exact shape of the Ninebot One frame was reconstructed by carefully crafting a total of six cross section sketches, that then were combined into the basic shape using the loft tool. The basic shape without any connecting contours is available as nb1shape.stl (and source nb1shape.fcstd)

title: Kossel Delta - gear and belt protector

description.text:
3D printing is fun! But many objects will fail trying to get the best results. Scraping the debris off the platform results in many fragments. See the first photo, showing the first prototype.
To protect these fragments falling into the space between gear and belt, I designed these simple protectors. An 'U-shaped' block is clamped between the two sheets. The two sheets are hold in place by a strip locking into the 15x15 alumium beam.

Feel free to download, print and use or even improve them.

Happing printing.

print_settings.Notes:: This .STL is set to FINE quality.  Because this print is so small, you may want to try 0.1 or 0.15 layer height for more detail (I used 0.2 and it was ok for my use). 3 inner, outer, and wall shells in Simplify 3D made it print solid for me without infill. PLA will yield best results but be careful installing since PLA can be brittle.  Print laying on its side with posts parallel with print bed. I could not get manual supports to print under the bottom clips and posts...maybe too small?  You will need to file down the edges of the bottom clips slightly to make the width of them fit in the metal walkway notches on loco.  FYI - Mine printed fine, but if your printer is not up to spec I could expect you to get stringing as it tries to print without supports under the notches and posts.

author: Reznikdmitry

description.text: In this project, students will discover the process of converting 2D drawings made on paper into 3D printed shapes. Each student will get 2 completed designs that can be combined with the rest of their class into unique and changeable sculptures. The process has several steps but the results are long lasting!

As art and specifically sculpture gains more and more interaction with digital manufacturing processes, this class is a great introduction to what is possible between this kind of technology and sculpture. Depending on grade level and computer access, the teacher might need to work outside of class to make it seamless.

Step 1: Introduction
  • Share sculptures that are modular and 3D printed from the References Section
  • Share pictures of what the outcome should be and the example STL connector pieces from this project’s thing files
    • Step 2: Drawing
  • Share the handouts with students
  • Pass out tracing paper and black marker
  • Students draw within the circle and include the cut out shape along multiple edges
    -See how creative students can be without going outside the circle size
    -The design needs to fit within the circle for the tinkercad sizing step!
    -Students can draw as many shapes as they want but should pick 2 to continue onto step 3!
    • TINKERCAD and 123D Design For instructions using MakerBot PrintShop, scroll down Step 3: Photographing or scanning
  • Scan or photograph the selected drawings one at a time
  • Keep the contrast high and if possible black and white
  • Crop out extra parts of the image (it should only be the art, not your hand and the edge of the paper)
    • Step 4: Converting to SVG
  • Go to: http://image.online-convert.com/convert-to-svg
  • Upload drawings to be converted
  • Convert File
  • The new SVGs will download into your downloads folder
    • Step 5: TinkerCad
  • Import SVGs into TinkerCad (they will import very large, but don’t worry!)
  • 1 circle is 50mm. Using the ruler tool, scale 1 circle down to 50mm x 50mm
  • Each circle is 3mm tall
  • Using the templates (connector hole template & pencil hole template) check size, and if necessary add to the drawings to make the cut out shapes more accurate and defined.
  • Export STLs
  • Bring into MakerBot Desktop and plate by what colors the student want for their designs (all red designs should be plated together, blue etc)
  • Print!
    • MAKERBOT PRINTSHOP variation Step 3-4: Printshop Photograph each drawing from the iPad app
    Step 5: Sizing in MakerBot Desktop Using the Scale Sub Menu in MakerBot Desktop, make the object 50mm by 50mm by 3mm (you might need to turn off uniform scaling) Step 6: Printing
  • 2 connectors per student should take ~1 hour
    • Step 7: Assembly
  • Take all the pieces and get building!
    1a. Supplemental Cardboard Connectors
    -Cut out circles from the handout
    -Tape the circles to cardboard
    -Cut around the shape
    -Tahda cardboard connector!
    -Color in with paint, pastel, etc for extra pop
    • Extension Activity This would replace the drawing component. A student would create the connectors completely on the computer.
  • Open the handout in Illustrator
  • Using the pen tool, draw a pattern inside the circle
  • Export the drawing as an SVG
  • Import the SVG into Tinkercad
  • Follow the original process
• 2-3 class periods - each student receives 2 connectors - a class of 30 students will have 60 connectors to play with plus as many supplemental cardboard connectors needed

To prepare for this lesson you will need the following supplies:
  • Computer/Chromebooks access (or iPad for Printshop)
  • Camera or scanner access
  • TinkerCad accounts
  • Handouts per student and extras printed
  • Cardboard
  • Pencils
  • Black marker
  • Tracing paper
  • Scissors

Grade as you would grade other art projects Handouts and Assets:
  • Svgartconnectorset_handout.pdf
  • 2 STL templates to be brought into Tinkercad as holes for precise cuts

Stackable Sculpture:
  • https://a.1stdibscdn.com/archivesE/upload/3558712/f_3681762/3681762_z.jpg
  • http://cdnstatic.visualizeus.com/thumbs/07/fb/generativeart,modularstructure,parametricarchitecture-07fbff47f49b98bf8fe7e0c3b820541e_h.jpg
  • http://static.squarespace.com/static/53402a9ce4b016f70ff71f5e/53407815e4b05778b71af7c4/534078efe4b05778b71b0e37/1396734191418/reach-sculpture-dror-3.jpg?format=original
  • http://www.thecreativehome.com/blogs/creative-home-reader/14746943-let-a-thousand-modules-bloom
    • 3D printed sculpture:
  • http://georgehart.com/sculpture/gyrangle.html
  • http://n-e-r-v-o-u-s.com/projects/albums/colony/
  • http://nickervinck.com/en
  • http://www.digital-grotesque.com/

Objectives
  • 2nd to 3d conversion
  • Drawing accuracy
  • Small components can make larger objects
  • Classroom Collaboration
  • Combing building material
Skills Learned (Standards)

VA:Cr1.1.3a : Elaborate on an imaginative idea.
VA:Cr1.1.2a : Brainstorm collaboratively multiple approaches to an art or design problem.

title: Xiaomi Yi and FPV cam tilt mount for flying wings

description.text:
This is a mounting system for attaching a Xiaomi Yi camera and micro FPV camera to a flying wing. The camera angle is adjustable for both cameras, although the Yi can only be tilted forward. M3 bolts go through the holes in the sides of the mount plate and thread directly into the holes in the Yi case. You'll want to use TPU or another similar flexible filament for the Yi case. To adjust the angle forward just use a higher set of holes on the rear. The case holds the Yi pretty tightly even upside down, but I'd put a rubber band or thin velcro strap around it just to be safe.

The FPV camera goes on the forward post and can be tilted forward or backward. I've included a mount for the micro 170 degree camera that Bangood sells. This mount is a minor remix from a mount that Arovillard created. You could also use his mount or another remix of it.

This is the camera that fits the FPV camera mount I've included:
http://www.banggood.com/600TVL-8_0MP-14-2_8mm-CMOS-FPV-170-Degree-Wide-Anlge-Lens-Camera-PALNTSC-p-984345.html

Required for assembly:
5 M3 bolts
1 M3 nut (preferably nyloc)

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

70%

Notes:

Print the Yi case out of TPU or a similar flexible filament. This case needs to be flexible for the camera to fit, and also for the M3 bolt threads to hold, since they thread directly into the case.

Print the mount plate and micro camera mount out of PETG or a similar material. You could also use PLA for this but the plate is more likely to break in a crash.

author: ashtondem

title: Replacement Stepper Drives for Replicator Dual Extruder

description.text:
I recently blew out both extruder motor stepper drives on my Makerbot Replicator Dual Stepstruder. I won't go into the reasons why but wanted to show my repair.

I don't think Makerbot sells parts for this unit (at least doesn't show them on their web site. I didn't call and ask) but would expect them to be quite expensive if they did.

I knew the stepper drive was blown when the stepper motor would just jitter back a forth a single step and the circuit board was extremely hot.

I replaced both stepper drivers with Pololu A4988 Stepper Motor Driver Carrier Boards, Item #1182 @ $5.95 each

https://www.pololu.com/product/1182/resources

These appear to be exactly the same board with one exception. The Pololu #1182 PCB uses a trim-pot to set the motor current where the Makerbot board uses a digitally (software) controlled voltage to set the motor current.

I don't think this is a big issue as it only needs to work, no acceleration is used on the extruder drives so this was not an issue.

Because of the difference in how they set the motor current, the pin out on the two boards is slightly different. Notice the "VR" pin on the Makerbot board is labeled "MS3" on the Pololu #1182 PCB.

I assume the "VR" is the variable motor current adjustment pin on the Makerbot board and the "MS3" is used to set the steps/revolution on the Pololu #1182 PCB.

To make the Pololu #1182 PCB compatible, I simply removed that pin when I soldered in the pin header (included with the Pololu #1182 PCB) and placed a jumper wire between the "MS3" solder pad to GND solder pad. MS1-MS3 is used to configure the step/rotation.

To set the correct motor current, I guessed that it should be about 1-amp or less. These boards are able to supply 2-amps with a appropriate heat sink and 1-amp without a heat sink. Since there is no heat sink on either board I decided to set the motor current to a conservative 800-mA.
According to the Pololu instructions, you do this by adjusting the trim-pot so that the voltage on the test point is 1/2 of the desired current (don't get lost in the weeds between mixing volts/current here). For 800-mA (0.8-Amps), I set the trim-pot so that the measured voltage was 0.400 Volts.

While this repair worked for me, I do not suggest anyone else do it as you would be exposed to dangerous voltages and temperatures and possibly further damaging your Replicator.

ALL RISK IS YOURS IF YOU CHOOSE TO SERVICE YOUR OWN REPLICATOR.

Refer all service to qualified service personnel.

Steps: (Read and understand all steps prior to doing any work on your Replicator).

  1. Solder the header pins to the Pololu #1182 PCB, don't install a pin at the MS3 position.
  2. Install a jumper between MS3 and GND solder pads.
  3. Set the trim-pot to the full-CCW position to set the motor current to 0-mA.
  4. Place the Pololu PCB into the Replicator. Note the orientation of the Pololu PCB, make sure the GND and Dir pins are at the same side as the original Makerbot PCBs.
  5. Place a digital volt meter between the GND and motor current test point.
  6. Turn on the Replicator and measure the voltage. It should be roughly 0-Vdc indicating 0-mA of motor drive current. Shut the Replicator off immediately if the voltage is above 0.4-VDC.
  7. Turn off the Replicator and remove the Pololu #1182 PCB.
  8. Turn the trim-pot slightly CW to increase the voltage and consequently the motor drive current.
  9. Repeat steps 4 through 9 until the voltage is approximately 0.400-VDC (800-mA motor drive current).
  10. This completes the repair, test using the load/unload filament utilities.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

comments.text: Thank you for this. My extruder motor got all twitchy tonight and I think the driver must have been burnt. I loan my trusty Original Replicator Dual out to other teachers every year, and one year it came back to me as a Replicator Single. I wasn't too upset, though, because idle nozzle ooze is annoying enough that I just avoid the dual extrusions.
comments.author: Dkesler

comments.text: Good to know, thanks for the info.
comments.author: DDStarkey

comments.text:
I did this operation whit the same steppers motors drivers (a4988), and applied the same 400 mV that you recomend. It works perfectly!
I bridge MS3 to Ms2, no problem whit that.
This is important: the z axis in the original replicator uses a diferent stepper motor, i can´t find the data sheet either, but it need less current, because with 400 mV the motor heat up a lot. I recomend less than 300mV. It wont loses step or heat up.
comments.author: Danieloses

comments.text:
I'm can't say for sure that you can/can't do that unless Makerbot uses Full Step, Half Step or Sixteenth Step modes of the A4988 chip.
See https://www.pololu.com/file/0J450/A4988.pdf for pin usage.
You might be correct as Full or Half step would be a reasonable choice.
You are right, if you pull the pin out of the header, you could tie the two pins together assuming the correct step mode is used.
The jumper to ground forces all modes except Sixteenth Step to operate correctly.
I think the heat sink is a great idea.
comments.author: DDStarkey

comments.text: Hi, I'm fairly certain you could just bridge MS3 to MS2 and avoid the jumper cable. That would make it possible to mount a heatsink if you wanted/needed more current. Nice hack though :-)

description.text:
The adapter between 1/4'' standard camera mount and HTC VIVE ball mount for lighthouse. The original adapter has been a incredible job, but as far as I try, I cannot put a standard 1/4'' nut in the center pocket, because the original design had only 10.5mm hole. (standard 1/4'' nuts have size of 11.1mm)

I could not find the proper nuts that maybe is used by original author. So I modified the original design little bit so that we can fit standard nuts can fit.

On the pictures, black one is original author's, and white one is new design.

Additional hardware needed:

1x standard tripod(1/4'') nut, having size less than 11.5mm
2x M5 screws
2x M5 nuts
(※ size of the nut here is defined by the distance between parallel edges, not vertices of the hexagon)

The modified FreeCAD file is supplied along with the generated STL file.

title: LED Integrated Lightsaber Internals
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is the a lightsaber I designed over a month or so. I integrated red and blue led's, which allows for Red, Blue, and Purple colors. I intended to create an outer sleeve that looks like a traditional lighsaber to put this in, but I don't currently have the time. Likewise with fixing some of the parts to be stronger or fit better. There are a few things I would redesign.

Print the pieces needed, and assemble it according to the explosion diagram. Some parts you will need to print multiples of, again see the diagram.

Most of the parts are glued together using ABS glue (I printed it in ABS). If you are using PLA, use epoxy. Of course you don't have to wire it up for LED's.

For ABS and PLA USE EPOXY TO ATTACH THE RODS AROUND THE CRYSTAL CHAMBER && print BatteryPartHooks at 100% infill, they like to break

Depending on the tolerance of your printer you will have to sand and in some placed drill to get a good fit.

Also important to note, there is a piece on the diagram that is a circle with two holes, instead use the SurfaceAreaMOD piece in its place.

Good luck!

This is a quad frame for 8.5mm brushed motors and has a shelf for an FPV camera housing.
Two versions: one with wire cutouts so you don't have to un solder your flight controller and motors. and one version with tighter motor mounts so they will never come loose. I have only tested the v3 frame. v4 is for when i crash, but I haven't broken v3 so why go to v4?!

My weight is about 64g with a 720mah 20C battery.

I used the Crazepony 200mw FPV camera.

All Parts are from Amazon:
8.5 mm hubsan generic motors must be H107D or C motors not L (L is 7mm motors)
syma 5c version 5 flight control board
crazepony 200mw FPV camera
720mah 20c battery

Flight time is about 5 minutes of great FPV. My only issue is the way the syma flight board controls the throttle. 10% throttle rockets the drone upwards. 100% same thing. and decrease from 100% does not result in descent. In a large field and minimal wind its fun to fly. Something to get you into fpv.

.2

100%

This project will help students illustrate their schema and creativity involving villains and monsters in fairy tales and fantastic stories.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Project Guidelines

Overview and Background
Students will design their own serpent-like antagonists based on the stories they have read in The Serpent Slayer. Students will learn what goes into a villain, why a larger or monstrous creature is usually the villain of folktales and how an artists’ interpretation can help enhance or detract from an author’s story. After students have brainstormed some designs based off the templates I will provide for them in ThinkCad they will spend some time in each class further developing pieces of their villains (head, body and feet). After all the pieces have been printed students will assemble their creature with assembly and tolerance procedures. Simultaneously students will be writing their own folktales based on their villains, using the same structure and morals they read about in the short stories the class read earlier. Students can also write backstories for their villains which would allow them to flesh out the world they have begun to create.

Objectives
Students will learn what goes into making an antagonist truly scary or worth worrying about. Students will design and create their own serpent-like antagonists. Students will understand the basics of 3D printing, design and tolerance.

Audiences
Elementary students in grades 4 and 5. While this lesson is focused on a specific book – The Serpent Slayer, its core objectives can be applied to most stories with a larger-than-life antagonist.

Subjects
This lesson ties into Reading / Language Arts, technology and art.

Skills Learned
CCSS.ELA-LITERACY.W.4.3
Write narratives to develop real or imagined experiences or events using effective technique, descriptive details, and clear event sequences.
CCSS.ELA-LITERACY.W.4.3.B
Use dialogue and description to develop experiences and events or show the responses of characters to situations.

Lesson/Activity Breakdown

  1. Make sure TinkerCad is available on a set of computers reserved before the lesson.
  2. Introduce the lesson after we have finished reading a story or two, including but not limited to the titular Serpent Slayer.
  3. Review the schema and information we’ve gathered about monsters and villains in folktales. Their size, demeanor, shape, attitudes and anything else we can gleam from their appearances as well as actions.
  4. Introduce the project and its parameters. Each student will be given a few templates; everyone will be starting with the same basic building blocks. Over the next few days we will we be designing our villains piece by piece based on our previous designs.
  5. Introduce/review the tools needed to create the villains students planned out.
  6. Students will complete the heads portion, save them to their computers and email them to their teacher.
  7. The teacher will begin printing them after class, hopefully in time for the next lesson.
  8. After looking at their headpieces students can notice any mistakes or things they would like to do differently. Afterwards students can begin to design the body portion.
  9. Upon completion of the body, they will repeat the aforementioned process to deliver their designs to their teachers. The teacher will begin printing them out as illustrated previously.
  10. Students will begin designing the feet/extremities of their villains. After they have sent them to the teacher they can begin brainstorming their stories.
  11. As a class, go over what a story needs. SWBS – Somebody (protagonist) Wanted (goal) But (conflict) So (resolution).
  12. While everything is being printed or fixed students will begin to write their stories on their computers using Microsoft Word.
  13. When students have completed their first drafts, they will buddy-edit before starting on their second drat.
  14. After a second drat and a second revision, students can begin their final draft.
  15. When students complete their stories the class will reassemble to review or introduce tolerance and assembly.
  16. Upon completion of the assignment students should have their own folktale and a villain to go with it.

Duration
This lesson could take as little as one week if everything were streamlined, but it could also be stretched out over an entire unit of short stories or folk and fairy tales.

Preparation
Students should be able to identify antagonists, character traits (both inside and outside) and be able to breakdown a story using the SWBS model.

Rubric and Assessment
Students should have a completed villain and story by the end of the assessment. Students can also grade on how well students were able to identify character traits and how well they implemented them in their model and story.

Materials
Teachers will need access to computers with internet capabilities, email or Drop Box accounts and a 3D printer.

title: Experimental Prusa X-carriage with auto tightening belt

description.text:
I take my extruder on and off my Prusa to change out the hot ends often. I love Gregâ€™s X carriage, but I find it takes some fiddling to retighten the belts. After seeing this, neat thing http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:16730 I wanted to try to build that concept into the X carriage, and while I was at it, try to reduce the hardware parts count. I tried to utilize the concept of a Drop Clamp which self tightens as strain is put on the wire. My thing is fixed on one side of the x carriage, and the other side uses the self tightening idea. As an afterthought I added one screw, and bolt hole (M4 or 6-32) to use if required to add a bit more tension if your belt still has some slop. The LM8UU bearing holder was copied from this thing, and then modified to suit my needs.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:15219 This was more an experiment to try the idea, as opposed to a finished product. I wanted to share with the community in the hopes that maybe it might inspire someone to build on the concept and reduce the hardware count.

Print. I used 25% infill and 3 shells at 0.5mm
There should be a single strand raft that was printed in between the teeth of one jaw. Remove with a knife, or pliers, or some other tool.
Clean up as per your usual routine with sandpaper, knife, emery board file.
Bend one side of the timing belt smooth side in thus exposing the teeth.
Insert the bent belt into the jaws fixed to the x carriage
Feed the other end of the belt through the box on the carriage and bend the belt again, smooth side in.
Insert the bent belt into floating jaw
In theory you should stretch the belt â€œtoo tightâ€ to clamp and set, and then when you insert the floating jaw into the box, it should settle at just the right tension. IF this system works, then you could have a belt holding system that does not use any metal hardware, and remove 4 M3 nuts, bolts and washer from the BOM. Reality and my 3D CADâ€™s are 2 vastly different things, so I quickly added the one screw/bolt tensioning system. If you so desire, add a M4, or 6-32 nut/bolt into the Jaw box holder, and tension the jaw with the screw. I have included the Google Sketch up file for others to modify and play with.

description.text:
A project that was inspired by the 3D printing Nerd. Here is a Taco holder in the shape of a Food Truck. It will hold 3 Tacos and is printed in 3 pieces, The Truck, the axle and the tires. This truck will snap together and has a connector in the back to act as a hitch.

More trailers will come in the future.

Progress/Updates below

LulzBot

TAZ 5

No

No

.32

20%

The axles may need a raft/brim if you have lifting. The ends of the axles are thin and might lift.

8/24/16: Taco Trailer added.

8/25/16: Error with the trailer, fixed and re uploaded.

8/26/16: Fixed Wheel wells on truck and trailer.

2/6/17: Added Taco Sauce Trailer. Will hold sauce packets and/or 7oz bottles of sauce (Like Cholula)

4/20/17: Added the Taco Truck Drinker Trailer. This should hold 2 12oz bottles or cans. This SHOULD work but hasn't been printed and tested yet. I'll be a test print later today, but though I would share it early. This Trailer will need 6 tires and the same axle for the Taco Truck itself. This trailer might need supports due to the larger wheel well in the back of the truck. If this is an issue I will probably go back to the dual wheel well design.

4/21/17: Did a test print of that tanker and it looks like the measurements I got for soda cans and bottles was sadly inaccurate(Thanks internet lol). So I've temporally removed it for now. I've already fixed the issue but I want to print it again before I post it. Sorry for any inconveniences. Also,I didn't need supports on the print, but your mileage may vary.

Fixed, Version 3 is now available.

9/10/17: Got a request for a CAD file of the trailers... but I made this in Tinkercad. If it can be converted somehow let me know. However, I did create three more basic trailers. Two with bigger bays on top, a single and a double and a blank flat trailer so others can make their own custom trailers. Also a special note, if you do make custom trailers let me know! I want to make sure to add links to them here so everyone can enjoy your remix!

We installed a dual extruder on a MakerGear M2. The default settings has the both hot ends extrude filament off the side of the print bed before printing. We found that sometimes the filament would harden on the spool of filament and cause it to become lodged in the filament feeder hole. We designed a shield that attaches easily with a small hex bolt and nut to the frame of the M2. Problem solved.

title: Case for ZX Spectrum DivSD Nano

description.text:
A quick protective case for the DivSD Nano (from July 2016 in case there are variants).
Not completely enclosing, and not actually fixed -- but slides down over the interface and protects it against fingers touching the PCB, like when kids without knowledge of the finer points of static electricity are using it.

If you are using a 48k machine, the NanoCase48 version has a little shielding in front also. On Amstrad machines, that might be too close to the computer case -- in that case, use NanoCaseAms instead.

Sketchup source included.

Notes:

Sliced for PLA using .24 layers, and -0.12 in Slic3r's XY Size Compensation to compensate for overflow at the small PCB groove.

Okay, I\'ll admit it, we have a BasicStamp board.  There I said it.  Before the flames descend, let it be known that there is also an Arduino system or two floating around and I have a similar project in mind for them.  Whew!
Okay, does your LCD just seem to always be in the way when working with your microcontroller?  Never fear, Makerbot to the rescue!  This odd little piece has a side slot where the edge of the LCD fits, and a hole for a #6 threaded rod in the bottom.  Make all 8 connections down to the center connector and free up your breadboard space!  You will lose pins 0 to 5 for this resource hog, and the code to run these things in pbasic is nasty, but it works!

Used ABS with the default Makerbot ABS skeinforge settings.  Still getting the hang of ABS shrinkage.  I apologize for the fact that you\'ll need to ream out the side slot and run a proper sized drill up through the bottom hole.  I used a 2 1/4 inch long #6 thread rod section for the post; length depends on how high up you want the display, but it does get top heavy.  I also used #22 solid wire to connect from the headers on the LCD to a double set of male headers cut to fit the stamp board, and the #22 wire is acting as a second support.

comments.text: Basic Stamp 2 FTW.*

title: Minimal (customizable) motor mounts for various toy quadrotors
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Inspired by the lightweight (but relatively expensive) fun the Tiny Whoop brings, this is a minimalistic frame replacement for various toy quadrotors that allows for building absolute minimum weight and size versions of them. Compatible quads are for instance the H8Mini or H101. The "frame" consists of 4 clips that are used for mounting motors directly to the flight controller PCB.

For use, disassemble the quad, print the four parts and glue them to the frame with a dip of hot glue. If you parallelize printing and quad dissassembly, you'll have a superlight quad within approx. 20 minutes ;)

See also these two blog entries for some more information: https://skmavs.wordpress.com/2016/08/25/a-superlight-3d-printable-frame-replacement-for-toy-quads/
https://skmavs.wordpress.com/2016/09/11/super-lightweight-fpv-quads-using-customizable-motor-mounts/

The frame has been created using OpenSCAD and is fully customizable. It gracefully deals with changes in dimensions and the motor diameters, lengths etc. can be modified using either the Thingiverse customizer or by opening using OpenSCAD and generating a stl file.

The model source is also hosted on github for version control and possible collaboration/forking: https://github.com/skohlbr/openscad_models/tree/master/mini_quad_motor_mount

Update August 26 2016

The sides of the model have been strengthened a bit, so it is more robust against breaking. The changes can be inspected using the diff tool on github.

Update September 11 2016

The mount has been improved significantly. It is now much more robust against breaking and the OpenSCAD model has been modified to allow specifying the desired propeller diameter and prop to prop distance. The size of the motor mount is then computed automatically. The changes relative to the original upload can again be viewed on github.
See also this posting going into some details about the changes: https://skmavs.wordpress.com/2016/09/11/super-lightweight-fpv-quads-using-customizable-motor-mounts/

PLEASE READ FIRST: this is a solid model of the vive controller NOT INTENDED TO BE USED TO REPLACE THE SHELL OF THE REAL CONTROLLER. it's to scale in millimeters. It's low poly with no manifold edges or any other problems that would make a boolean difficult. as such the size and location of the sensor reflectors are correct but they are not an accurate representation of the sensors. I designed this so I could made custom controller attachments. it has worked well. also note I have not used the top of the controller for any modding yet. I have the screw holes accurate on that part because I thought that might be helpful. but it might cause a boolean issue. The side grip buttons have been extended out so that when this model is subtracted from another. they should sit comfortably in there. realized after completing a print this was not the right scale. not sure how it got incorrect but i suspect some program converted from MM to inches. everything is still to scale. it's just the wrong scale. don't have time to fix right now. just didn't want anyone to fail a print because of my mistake.

I've gotten R&P working on the Wallace X-Carriage. Unfortunatly, my thermister fell out of the hot-end with predictable results. :( Video Now available:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hdH4k7Sb1UA Octopus 1 was printed before the X R&P mod was added.
Octopus 2 is Full R&P 48mm/s shells 4"(100mm) circle 1"(27mm) high single wall printed at 75mm/s

Print all parts. Remove the X-Motor and ideler bearings from Wallace. Remove the old X-carriage from rails and install new. Use 10mm m3 bolt to hold bottom liner bearing in place.
(Hole in Motor plate for driver access.) Put 6mm threded rod through the Rack. measure against X-ends to make sure Rack covers bed. Add nuts to each end of Rack to secure. Drop X-stage to bottom/home position. Put 6mm mounts on rod and adjust carefully to match the holes for the Ideler bolts. Bolt into place with original Ideler bolds and nuts. Put Pinion on X-motor. Lave about 1mm space between motor and Pinion. Place motor on X-carriage motor mount and check Pinion hight. It should match the Rack. Mount motor with same 10mm M3 bolts. Slide motor against Rack.
Hold gently and chack for smooth motion. Too much pressure against Rack will cause ripples. Too little will cause backlash. Once happy with smooth motion, tighten bolts. (rear bolts are difficult to install and may not be nessessary, unit has worked without them.) RE-ADJUST your firmware for X-motion.
77.4790 works for me. CORRECTION!!!
76.7480 Note! Any variance in the printer making the Rack will affect the Rack motion distance. You must make your own distance mesurments! Now Print stuff! :)

print_settings.Notes:: I always use rafts because my printer does not work well without them.  I printed two different imprints at the same time, but the prints started to lift.  I stopped the print before it was done, but I had enough of the leaf to use in the lesson.

description.text: Students will be creating a 3D models of leaves which other students will attempt to identify using plant characteristics.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

10%

Notes:

I always use rafts because my printer does not work well without them. I printed two different imprints at the same time, but the prints started to lift. I stopped the print before it was done, but I had enough of the leaf to use in the lesson.

How the leaf print is made

A sketch of a leaf was found using a Google search. The drawing was then converted into an .svg file which was imported into Tinkercad. Have a solid surface, the leaf drawing was made into a hole and imprinted onto the surface. This was then printed out.
NGSS CCSS

Students will learn about the structure and design of leaves while modelling a print of them in 3D. They will then use a dichotomous key to classify the leaves of others in the class. Objectives Students will be able to:
  • Model a leaf in 3D using Tinkercad software
  • Use a dichotomous key to identify trees
    • Standards Students should understand the unifying concepts of science, and should in addition understand: Similarities and differences among animals, plants, fungi, microorganisms, and viruses Students should know how to develop and use models to represent things in nature.

The lesson should begin with a description of the various leaf descriptors:
Branching: Alternate vs Opposite
Deciduous: Broad-leafed, compound leaf, leaflets, petiole, simple leaf, veins
Conifers: bundles, coniferous, evergreen, scaly
Leaf Margins: Entire, Lobed, Toothed, Sinuses Then students should be assigned a specific leaf to design. Students can find this leaf online, or sketch the leaf out themselves and scan it into the computer. The students will then convert their file to an .svg file for import into a program like Tinkercad. (I used online converter software http://picsvg.com/ because it shows the before and after picture to make sure I get the file that I want) Students will then import this file into Tinkercad and create a hole with it to create an imprint. The file will then be downloaded into a form suitable for 3D printing. After the imprints have been made, students will do a "gallery walk" to each of the leaves and use their dichotomous chart to identify each leaf. Screenshot of PicSvg conversion. .svg file use to imprint solid block MakerBot Desktop 3.9

3D Printer
Computer for each student with internet access
Student accounts for Tinkercad
Dichotomous charts for each group of students
Life-size images of leaves (preferably black and white)

The designing and identifying should only require (1) 45 minute class, but the printing will take much longer depending on the number of models and the print capacity. It is recommended that one day be spent creating the model, then have this revisited once the prints are complete to use the dichotomous key to identify the models.
Students will be graded on the accuracy of their model and their ability to identify the models of others.

• http://static.nsta.org/files/PB233Xweb.pdf
  • http://www.uwsp.edu/cnr-ap/leaf/Documents/U78_FE1.pdf

title: Mazzer burrs on Kitchenaid grinder adapter plate

description.text:
These plates are what is needed if you have a kitchenaid Proline espresso / coffee grinder, and you wish to fit some decent burrs.
The Mazzer Mini burrs are a close fit, but need some minor adaption to fit. If the adaption is your problem, this is your solution.
Edit: Just to clarify: The Mazzer mini and Mazzer mini E take different size burrs! This conversion is specifically for the Mazzer Mini.

I am not the creator of this, I am merely the person posting it on behalf of the creator.
Full details in this thread:
http://www.coffeegeek.com/forums/espresso/grinders/702489

I will also be posting a link in the thread to this, so it can be accessed by all.

I have not printed this yet, will update when I have. I would print it with 100% infill for max strength, and make VERY sure it's level afterwards.

Update: Looks like I won't be able to test it myself in the foreseeable future, however in the comment section user kimand85 has indeed printed and fitted it.

If you have a CNC machine, aluminium would of course be best! :)

Hi! Apologies for no progress, my printer is in the process of getting a complete rebuild, so I've been lurking for a while...
If you check the thread mentioned in the main description you'll find plenty info on how this works. As long as the plastic parts are printed with solid infill, and gets some sanding on a plate of glass to make sure it's perfectly level and straight, I think it has a good chance of success. Jan

title: Carrera Go 1:43 Slotcar VW Touareg Chassis with slide guide
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a replacement chassis for the original one.
The original one has a simple pin for the slot and a magnet, so that it doesn't slide.

This is a chassis for a slide guide which allows you to drive over obstacles and slide.
It is designed for the Ninco slide guide 80104

Here you can find the parts for the BMW X3 Dakar
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1739197

Videos on Youtube
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OcNV0RwdAtk
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JPuhrFuYETk

Instructions

Print every part once.

You have to cut the original pin from the body so that there is enough space for the slide guide.

Glue Touareg_chassis_part1 und Touareg_chassis_part2 together.
To mount the touareg_guide_mount to the chassis, I use a needle.

Use a spring from a pen to push the guide_mount with the slide guide to the rails when driving over obstacles. Cut a small mart out of it and try how it fits and works.

There is an extra hole in the chassis for the LED from the decoder. I modified all my cars with the decoder from the 1:32 Carrera Digital cars.

Parts to print

1x touareg_chassis_part1
1x touareg_chassis_part2
1x touareg_front_wheel_mount
1x touareg_rear_wheel_mount
1x touareg_guide_mount
1x touareg_motor_mount
1x touareg_pin

This chassis is designed for the Ninco slide guide 80104
http://www.nincoshop.de/ninco-80104-leitkiel-standard-mit-schleifer-4-x-neu-ovp.html

10x M2 screws
I use this one http://www.banggood.com/200pcs-M2-Allen-Bolt-Hex-Socket-Round-Cap-Head-Screw-Assortment-Kit-Set-Black-p-1041363.html?p=OF26119123132014119R

description.text:
Remix of gsimpson2g's cable chain mount (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1519519/).

I wanted to change the orientation of the mounts, as it gives me more buildspace in the z-direction and I think it looks better. I did quite a few changes, including lowering the profile, making it open, making it stronger etc.

The awesome cable chain by RotoScan can be found here:

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:11978

25/08-2016: Cleaned up the extruder mount a little.

28/08-2016: I made brackets to lower and move the LCD back. This gives free passage for the chain and the extruder http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1740994

comments.text: This worked great! good design, thanks
comments.author: sprt8400

comments.text:
Hi,
may i ask you what settings you used to get that printed so well? I'm having troubles with this machine and i can't set it properly to get the best result possible. My extruder has a 0.3mm nozzle diameter and 1.75mm PLA filament. I tried with a 0.3 layer at 190°C with 65°C heated bed but the object is not clean and sharp edges are not sharp at all, not to mention the holes.
Thank you for your attention! Bye
comments.author: Loren94

comments.text: Did you have any luck? I can tell you that a .3 layer height with a .3 nozzle is really asking for trouble.. although im shooting in the dark here try 205 nozzle 60 bed and .2mm layer height if you know how set your print speed to something like 30 or 40mm/s i know defaults can be 50mm/s+ on some slicers and machines...
comments.author: Loren94

comments.text:
Hi Loren94,
Cannot remember the exact settings, but it's printed in ABS with a 0.4 nozzle. Probably around 230C with 0.2 mm layers. If you print it in PLA I would suggest that you print both at the same time to give the PLA some time to set/cool between layers. Both items printed standing upright (not like in the preview thumbnail, but like in the picture). You should have support for the extruder part.
Good luck

title: Customizable caliper adapter for soft materials (easier thickness measurement)

description.text:
I work a lot with soft foams lately. I tried using my caliper to measure their thickness, but the result depends a lot on the pressure i applied.

These dish adapters give me better, repeatable results, because they increase the contact area between the foam and the caliper and thus the force needed to compress the material.

The STL is for a standard caliper.

Notes:

Would print this in PLA to increase chance of having flat dishes.
I designed this under a dim candle light

author: luciandepold

description.text:
This is our first model created by a student in our school to print on our Makerbot!
This gun started as a high-resolution modelling assignment in 3D Studio. Andrew designed, modelled and cut up the gun so it could be printed in our Makerbot.

1) Print all the pieces (Revolver_full is just to see the competed mesh). We used silver for all parts except the grips and the sights, which were black. I used a raft for the smallparts, the sights and the barrel; everything else printed just fine without it.
2) To make the barrel able to spin, we inserted a small piece of filament through the centre hole and into the small indends in the lefthalf. You may have to widen the center hole of the barrel with a small drillbit. I also carved out these 2 indents a bit for the filament to fit.
3) Insert the barrel and glue the lefthalf to the righthalf (place a bit of glue on the filament inserted into the lefthalf).
4) Cut off support pieces on each grip.
5) Glue grips together. Then glue them onto the gun.
6) Glue trigger, hammer, and sights into place.
That's it, have fun. Warning!! This looks a lot like a real gun, be careful.

This is an Ankh designed after an Ancient Egyptian Artifact. It's basically a golden key shape with some hieroglyphs imprinted into it. I created this in Fusion 360 using the sketch tool to trace the reference image I brought in.

Then I printed it out on my Robo3D R1 printer. I printed it 0.3mm layer height because you don't gain much from smaller layer heights. No supports are needed.

Then my wife sanded the crap out of it to get a smooth finish. Then she primed it, painted it gold using spray paint, then used a wash to darken the cracks of the hieroglyphs.

Print Settings:
Printer: Robo 3D R1
Filament: Hatchbox PLA
Layer Height: 0.3mm
Infill: 15%
Supports: No
Raft: No

title: Rostock Max V2. PLA Cooling Unit

description.text: In order to have good PLA print, you need to cool it as quick as you can from all sides. With Rostock Max V2 effector, you can put up to 3 blower fans for PLA cooling. However, you only get one blower fan in the kit. To cool from all sides, you will need to buy 2 more blower fans. This means you have to spit more wires to feed the other 2. To avoid all that, I designed a new blower fan unit that can direct air from the blower to all 3 sides. You will need 3 small screws and some crazy glue to put together 3 printed pieces. See images on how they are glued together and how to mount it. You can print the whole thing with no supports.

This is a 4x4 equivalent to be used with an Arduino Pro Micro. Made as a Macro keyboard for my wife, so she can use a few shortcuts handy while using her Wacom keyboard.

You can search ebay for "Keyboard Keys Metal Panel SPST Machine Pushbutton Switch". You can even simply buy the plate and use different switches (like Cherry MX ones).

Pictures show an early version, I had mistakenly measured the inner dimensions of the switch plate instead of the outer. It still fit, but not very comfortably, the files here are for a better version where everything fits nicely.

A simple code sample (and the one I actually used in this project) can be found here: https://github.com/nariox/4x4arduinokeyboard

Possible improvements:

  • I didn't draw the holes for screws, I just drilled some on top, but it's not extremely strong.

description.text:
The lightsabers of the legendary Jedi and Sith Lord, Revan! This includes both designs from Knights of the Old Republic and from The Old Republic.

Each saber is labeled "TOR" and "KotOR" respectively. Be sure to print 4 of the Emitter guards, 3 Grip A's and 3 Grip B's for the TOR hilt. If you find that the whole Emitter Guard will not fit on your bed, I included it split into two parts labeled 'SPLIT Emitter Guard - Top and Bottom'. All of the STLs are in the orientation I printed them, personally I printed the Emitter Guards with support generated in Cura (if using the split emitter guards, that would correspond the Top piece). That is the only supported piece.

It is best when assembling the TOR saber to stack all of the necessary pieces and then slide the Emitter Guards through all of the pieces. Happy Printing!

description.text:
UPDATE:
I've added a frame with a mounting hole so that this system could be attached to a wall. I've not printed one but I imagine it should work.

UPDATE:
I've redesigned the slots that the dividers fit into, they now run across the bottom of the tray as well. Previously I had issues with small items slipping between compartments, this alteration resolves this. I've made the slots deeper and tweaked the divider design. All the parts should now work as I originally intended.

UPDATE:
So I've printed the final four frame sections in order to finish this section of my build off and I've noticed that the sections don't fit very tightly together. They don't fall apart but they aren't a snug fit like they were previously.
I've recently made some mods to my extruder drive to try to improve the resolution and I think the improved tolerance is the problem.
To try to improve the situation I have added some tiny "bumps" to the female mortise areas (they are only 0.25mm high so I don't think they show on the preview image). I haven't tried printing it yet and I don't plan on it any time soon so I would be interested to find out whether it has helped if anyone tries the design out.

Linking storage system that I designed to hold all my 3D printer spares.
Frames simply slot together
Trays can be separated into 1,2 or 3 compartments as required.
To get to the point in the photo has taken weeks-this thing takes forever to print but it has helped organise all the nuts, bolts and other parts I have laying around so it has been worth it in the long run and should I need more storage I can just slide another module in.

Supports:

No

Notes:

Should work with any settings really.

comments.text: Hey, i have an other advise/request, inside the piece are holes, and they all have a chamfer that let if you print it from bottom to the top a place where it is parrallel to the print bed making a 0% angle and requier a support for printing, is it possible to make a full angle/chamfer for not letting this parrallel surface ? it would be a waste of plastic during the printing :/
comments.author: JonnyBrylcreem

comments.text:
Hi
Thew frame sections will print without support. The parallel sections are pretty short and you should be able to bridge the gaps with ease. The shape of the frame also makes the vertical sections very stiff when being printed so they shouldn't move around either.
I try to avoid using support and additional cooling wherever possible as my printer isn't currently set up for this. I find that support material never breaks away cleanly so all my designs tend to be self supporting.
